metadata.title: 5 AI Pitfalls for Business & How to Avoid Them | by Was Rahman | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5 AI Pitfalls for Business & How to Avoid Them
metadata.description: With AI still in its infancy in the business world, there are plenty of ways for AI to go wrong. And there’s still limited widespread knowledge on how to avoid AI pitfalls. Many are technical, but…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: drawing incorrect, inappropriate or invalid conclusions
sometimes AI teams just don’t take an interest.
AI project as a learning exercise

all_paragraphs: With AI still in its infancy in the business world, there are plenty of ways for AI to go wrong. And there’s still limited widespread knowledge on how to avoid AI pitfalls.
Many are technical, but some aren’t. Businesspeople can play a valuable role in flagging risks, especially those with significant business impact.

This article lists some important AI pitfalls relevant to AI business stakeholders, with tips to steer around them. They’re a result of the anecdotal, personal and published experience of AI projects that could have gone better.

If things go wrong with an AI project, the best case is usually wasted investment or missed opportunity. For example, failing to keep up with competitors. In worse cases, AI may inflict damage to some aspect of your business. Casualties can include sales growth, customer satisfaction, brand or operational efficiency.

Business members of the AI team can’t do much about many AI project problems. That’s because they require data science or technical expertise. But it’s valid for them to be involved — or at least aware — of those that have significant business impact.

Asking the right questions may be enough to reduce the likelihood of many problems happening. However, it’s easy to bog down your project with excessive caution or irrelevant concerns if the questions are uninformed. Educating yourself on the kinds of things that can go wrong, and why, is a good way of remaining constructive.
Below is an overview of 5 common AI pitfalls that businesspeople should be aware of. They directly relate to business aspects of the work, and overall business success.

A common AI pitfall is drawing incorrect, inappropriate or invalid conclusions from the results of AI work. As with all statistics and data science work, there is interpretation required to ascribe meaning to data. If that isn’t done well, the results are vulnerable to misinterpretation and inappropriate use. That’s particularly prevalent where business leaders have pre-existing decisions or instincts they’re looking to justify with data.
This isn’t usually a wilful result. It could well happen because of haste, ambiguity or misunderstanding around the business question(s) being asked of the AI solution.

If there’s pressure to produce results quickly, it’s easy to over-simplify what you ask AI to do. Initially, it’s usually possible to distil a project to one overarching goal and associated AI “big question(s)”. But as you drop into detail, the complexity can become daunting.
Assuming everyone is sincerely seeking the “right” answer, there are two main project steps where this AI pitfall appears:

Let’s say you’re struggling with customer retention. It’s tempting to ask your AI team to identify customers who are going to leave. It seems reasonable that if you know that, you could do something to prevent them going.
When they ask how accurately you want to identify them, a natural answer might be “as accurately as possible”, ideally 100%.

The flaw here is that if customers leave because of unhappiness, the likelihood of leaving increases with dissatisfaction. The more accurately you want to predict a customer will leave, the later in their lifecycle the answer appears.
In other words, you can best predict they’ll leave when they’re most dissatisfied. Unfortunately, it’s likely to be too late to do much about it by then.

Looking again at the “big picture” question, it would be more useful to uncover earlier signs of increasing dissatisfaction. This translates into using AI to “score” how likely customers are to leave in the future. Knowing this, you could try different interventions earlier to change minds.

With the second type of “wrong question” AI pitfall, the pitfall doesn’t appear initially. That’s because the solution initially yields useful results. It’s only with longer-term validation, testing or use that the flaws appear.
A painful, well-documented example from recruitment is using AI to screen CVs or assess candidates.

The problem arises by using AI to infer characteristics of ideal candidates from employees who’ve succeeded in the past. This will encourage the firm to hire future staff “in its own image”. New hires should do well, because they’re similar to those who already do well.

The pitfall is that the AI logic won’t just replicate what’s good about existing employees. It may also reinforce less desirable behaviours. Firms falling foul of this inadvertently embedded pre-existing biases and prejudices into their hiring process. In the worst cases, this included illegal ones related to race or gender.

The root cause here also lies with the question asked of the AI team by business. It appears in its implications for AI solution design, and longer term results. A typical flawed question might be “identify candidates who will succeed in our organisation”. Without further qualification and constraint, it leads to this kind of problem. But the problem won’t appear until much later than the first type. It will initially appear to work well, picking candidates who fit comfortably into the firm.

One mitigation is allowing enough time to model different data science approaches to generate possible answers. Also, make sure you understand the underlying logic and assumptions in business terms. Involve business in evaluating interim results and “sense-checking” them from a business perspective.

Another way to avoid these kinds of difficulty is to play out how the AI results will be used in business terms. This should continue all the way through to realising the benefits. It’s also worth trying to extrapolate into the longer term. This means visualising what will be different in the business with the solution in place for a few quarters, and then a few years.
There are useful techniques to use in AI solution design that help sidestep this. These include business prototyping and scenario planning.

There are plenty of articles, conference sessions and books describing how AI can help business. But there’s much less about how to quantify those benefits. When people talk or write publicly about their AI benefits, numbers aren’t mentioned very often.

This leads to a dilemma for businesses spending on AI. Without benchmarks and quantifiable benefits, AI business cases are unlikely to meet the same standards as other budgets. But when everyone seems to be talking about how AI will transform business, not doing AI work seems questionable. Even if the numbers are vague or don’t quite stack up.

Even if the reasons for the dilemma are known, the response can be less understandable. When the topic is AI, some businesses embark on potentially expensive work, without clarity on what they hope to achieve from it. Some justify this because AI is likely to be strategically important in the future. But arguably, that makes setting a destination even more important.
Yet the experience of many AI practitioners is that quite a few firms do this. Unsurprisingly, this can cause disappointment or scepticism about AI, and the pausing of nascent AI plans.

There are several ways of working around this. One is grouping the spend with existing investments and cost centres, such as R&D or capability building. Another is setting “soft” business goals, consciously accepting more latitude on measuring results. A third is using initial projects to creating a baseline of relevant metrics for future business cases.
There are two parts to addressing this pitfall, which should be treated separately:

Both can be tricky, and there are few useful industry reports or benchmarks available yet to provide quick answers. But each is achievable, and those who persevere will find themselves ahead of most of their competitors.
AI business projects create outputs for business people to use to solve a business problem or improve a business activity.

To solve the problem or improve the activity, you’ll need to modify day-to-day work to make use of the AI output. So it seems obvious that deciding how a business will use the AI output should be part of the AI work.
Unfortunately, it doesn’t necessarily work that way in practice.

It’s not that AI teams don’t recognise business changes need to happen. In many organisations, it’s not part of their responsibility. In others, AI teams don’t have the knowledge or authority to do anything meaningful about it. Of course, sometimes AI teams just don’t take an interest. Or they know it’s difficult, so leave it to someone else.

As with other aspects of AI work, there’s a good analogy with regular IT work. In both, it’s not uncommon to find business teams and IT teams appearing to work against each other. The reasons may be political, human or historical, but the result is teams that don’t seem to be working for the same organisation. It doesn’t help that AI technical work is harder to understand, and its long-term implications less clear. So this divide can be much more stark in AI projects, especially if business teams feel threatened by AI.

It’s not possible to prescribe generically how your AI projects should handle business implementation. It varies by organisation, solution type and even department. But you can establish some principles for AI business implementation across your organisation. These can then become part of your approach to all AI work.
The aim is not to do AI business implementation perfectly. It’s to make sure you don’t overlook business implementation or relegate it to an afterthought.

Deciding what skills to employ or engage for your AI work is difficult if your organisation doesn’t really understand AI. Also, deciding what skills you need is a function of strategic decisions you may not yet have made.
These factors lead to two types of AI pitfall related to skills:

If you plan to use third parties for AI work, you’ll need in-house AI skills to commission and manage work. You’ll also need them to assess those you pay to do that work. Conversely, if you keep AI work in-house, you’ll need an in-house AI team, with very different profiles.
If you haven’t decided between the two, it’s hard to know what skills you’ll need. A possible exception is an AI leader to make such decisions and plan accordingly.
AI hiring is even trickier, because there’s little consensus on what an AI team or department should look like. There’s even debate about where in a firm AI should sit.

One mitigation option early on in your AI skills building is to focus on broader AI knowledge for your initial hires. This allows you to avoid over-specialising permanent hires until you have clarity on longer term skills needs. While building that clarity, use contract or cross-trained existing IT staff for the more detailed roles, especially technical development.

Just like any other specialisation, high level labels (e.g. data scientist or data engineer) are often meaningless without context. Assessing someone’s capabilities is tricky if you don’t have the knowledge to distinguish fact from exaggeration from fiction. Similar challenges exist when selecting AI vendors to build your AI solutions.

It will be risky to delegate AI hiring or procurement to people without sufficient AI knowledge to overcome these challenges. You will also need to give them sufficient guidance to evaluate and compare candidates.
An easy AI pitfall to fall foul of is starting AI work primarily because of a desire to use AI. This usually goes hand-in-hand with insufficient thought on the kind of problem to solve with it.
This leads to AI projects without business focus, or that are trying to solve the “wrong” kind of problem. This includes problems for which AI is not suitable, or unable to help resolve.

I’m not elaborating here on what makes for the right kind of problem for AI. There are checklists and other resources to help you identify what to look for in a problem to assess its suitability for AI. The emphasis here is on making sure you’ve considered carefully your choice of AI project and problem. The important point is that someone has looked at “why AI” for the problem at hand. If they believe it’s a valid match, the explanation should be understandable by business leadership, not only AI specialists.

Ideally, you’ll choose the right kind of problem, and things will go well. But don’t be disheartened if, despite trying, they don’t. Teams make mistakes choosing the right business problem, particularly early in an organisation’s adoption of AI. But that improves over time. It’s an almost inevitable part of converting AI information into knowledge.
To avoid this pitfall, look for symptoms that a desire to use AI is driving a project. Alternatively, it may be easier to spot the lack of a suitable business problem.
AI for its own sake is a pitfall. However, it’s worth noting that an AI project as a learning exercise can have benefits. These may be strong enough by themselves to justify this approach.

If you’re following that path, it should be an explicit decision to invest in AI project for learning. The business case for such investments is very different, as is what to measure and achieve for success.

It’s still early days for AI in business, and the industry is still figuring out answers to fundamental questions. One is the best way to consistently build effective AI business solutions. Another is how to achieve measurable business improvements from AI work. A third is deciding the skills your business needs to compete in an AI world. Bear in mind that fitting those skills into an existing organisation structure isn’t necessarily straightforward.
As a result, many AI projects don’t “succeed”, perhaps the majority. So today, knowing how to avoid AI pitfalls is arguably as important as knowing how to build AI business solutions.

Many pitfalls are technical in nature, and businesspeople have limited opportunity to do much about them. But others relate directly to business aspects of AI work, and business stakeholders can influence them strongly.

We’ve discussed five here. Four are about doing AI work for the right business reasons, and ensuring AI work results in measurable business results. The fifth is about the significant organisational implication on the AI skills a business needs.

It’s usually a given that businesses do AI work for business gain. But that’s not always the focus of an AI team, especially if grappling with technical and data problems. Teams may even treat business issues as an unwelcome distraction.

As an AI business stakeholder, a key responsibility is to ensure appropriate business focus in AI projects. This should be in place from the outset, and remain sharp throughout — including after the project ends. Attention to the pitfalls discussed here should help achieve this.
This article was first published on www.aiprescience.com
CEO of AI research & consulting firm AI Prescience. Author of “AI & Machine Learning” (SAGE). 30+ years experience using data & technology to improve business.
